content:
y 21, 2015
												Cthulhu Saves the World is an RPG with new twists on an old formula. If you haven't already, you should look at my (or any) review on Breath of Death VII by the same developers prior to this game. Cthulhu Saves the World does a lot to expand on that. For those of you who don't want to bother looking at that first... well get ready for this review then.Cthulhu Saves the World has all your basic RPG stuff in it, leveling up, equipment management, going from town to town, talking to people, random encounters, spells, a four person party... all that good stuff. And the story, basically, is that Cthulhu has had his powers taken from him. In order to restore them, he must become a hero. Of course, being an evil creature such he, this makes for some goofy situations and banter between characters, the narrator, and Cthulhu himself along the way. So what makes this game stand out exactly?Well, if that premise of playing as a reluctant hero isn't enough, consider some of these things. The combat consists of a basic attack, technical attacks, and spells. Technical attacks and spells take MP. Using most moves will result in your combo going up, based on the number of hits. There are some moves that are very powerful or very useful, but may break this combo when used. There are also a few moves that are combo finishers. This means that the higher the combo, the more damage these moves will do. This is very useful to take advantage of on bosses. There's also a status effect in this game called insanity. Generally, moves that cause insanity will be quite powerful, and enemies that are insane may increase your stats a bit based on your passive skills. However, insane enemies tend to do more damage as well, so it can be a risky trade off. Another neat thing is that, upon leveling up, you can choose to select one of two available upgrades. They might be increased stats, new moves, enhanced old moves, passives, or any combination of the choices. This gives some good replayability and customization options. To really appreciate this game, you have to look at where it shines... convenience. This game is clearly designed by people who know how annoying RPGs can be, and they have taken measures to try and lessen the natural burdens of the genre. One way is simply allowing you to move around faster at the push of a button. There's also the ability to teleport to any city you've been to at any time, which is really nice for fast travel. The fights can move along quickly, which is nice for grinding. Animations for attacks are short, enemies are still images, and the display gives you fast information. After a battle, you will have some MP restored, full HP restored, and all party memebers revived... provided that you won. This makes it very easy to keep moving forward. No need to hoard healing items, use up MP on healing outside of battles, or travel back to healing areas. But by far the best addition is how this game handles random encounters. You see, every area has its own set number of random encounters. This means you'll find battles randomly that many times in the area. Once you've fought that many battles, the number reaches zero and you will no longer encounter enemies there randomly. This allows you to focus on your exploring, which is super nice in the mazier places. However, if you wish to grind in an area even after all the random encounters are up, you can! Simply go to the menu and select the option called fight. Then you will get to find a battle immediately without walking around randomly. It's the best of both worlds and I really love this feature.The art style is cool, basically a 16 bit type of representation, more or less. Colorful areas and monsters, plus I really like the neat attention to detail with the in-battle backgrounds that change depending on the area and terrain. A nice touch that made me get a little more into it. I can't speak for the music since I had the sound off while grinding and watching stuff... so sorry but... grinding. Some of the dialogue can be pretty funny at times. Sometimes not so much, but it depends. There's even a cool mode you can turn on to get little notes from the developer in the game about its development. It's neat! Also, I'd like to bring up that there are some fun bonus modes to try out here too. I personally really liked the Cthulhu's Angels bonus mode, which is almost a totally new campaign aside from many of the areas and enmies reused. New story and dialogue, not to mention new characters, made it well worth going through. However, there are some bad things about the game. The extra modes are among them. The higher difficulties are just more frustrating, as is highlader mode which only lets you use one person at a time to fight. These seem more like filler modes than actually being more conent, and for a game that's designed for the ease of use, making harder modes seems a bit counterproductive. But it's for more harcore players I guess. The other issue with the game is that, while it does try to fix the natural burdens of classic RPG design, it simply treats the symptoms rather than curing the problem. Basically, while it does make those aspects more enjoyable, it still has them.In the end, Cthulhu Saves the world is a really fun RPG for those who like simpler RPGs and want a smooth experience with a classic feel. I can only seem to find it in a package with Breath of Death VII for 3 bucks, and even for just this game, it's worth it. If you want to know more about Breath of Death VII, check out my review of that (or other people's reviews) and see for yourself. It's basically the same as this, but smaller and a little less polished. I'd say that if you get the pack, play that first to really appreciate the changes in this one. It's a pretty good deal for what you get. Cthulhu Saves the World gets an 8/10 for being a solid classically styled RPG with some great innovations to make the old formula much more enjoyable.

content:
2, 2016
												Cthulhu Saves the World: Super Hyper Enhanced Championship Edition Alpha Diamond DX Plus FES HD - Premium Enhanced Game of the Year Collector's Edition (without Avatars) is a very fun game that exceeds my expectations. As the 142 runner up in the 2011 game of the year award, I feel that it should be very proud. Pros:+Decent graphics, although I had to turn texture detail down a bit, ant the anti-aliasing was difficult to configure.+The gameplay is very simple to pick up, as it only took 18 hours of various Reddit PDFs to get down to the nitty-gritty with it.+This game contains the only known footage of Cthulhu facepalming, which is invaluble to many hardcore followers.+Before its release on Steam, I clocked 7,000 hours in it, requiring me to hire people to remind me to eat and drink.+AAA graphics exceeding that of BO3, max settings.+Heart-wrenching story leaves you wanting more to the very end.Cons:-Even with Crossfire SLI, the animations were a bit too much to handle. My Titan X cards running overclocked were struggling to pull the load above 20 FPS.-There is no resolution setting above 2048x4096, which is very dissapointing, making it difficult to read the text when playing it on my 12K 90" flatscreen.-The lowest settings look awful, and it is my only option, otherwise, the game crashes.-It seems that the microtransaction for the avatars is broken, as that is the only thing between me and owning all of the DLC.Overall: 7.825/10. The story is well written, and cross-refrences with The Dunwich Horror reveals that no bounderies are overstepped in the plot, and therefore, the canon remains intact. The graphics are amazing, and the photorealistic rendering payed off. However, the game runs slower then a whale on land. Perhaps it is due to my mere 128 gigs of 2400 mhZ ram, but something leads me to believe that that will suffice. The soundtrack is OK, but it seems that the devs forgot to turn down the DUNGEON_VICTORY.OGG by .23 decibles, because Sony Vegas revealed in post-production that the volume was simply too loud. The controller support is fantastic, and the only drawback is that my Xbox One Elite controllers wireless dongle failed to connect properly. If the devs prove able to fix these simple bugs, then I would have no problem upping their score to a maximum of 9.735. Lovecraft would be proud. Lovecraft would be proud.

content:
6, 2014
												Cthulhu Saves the World is a love letter to the SNES-era turn-based jRPG. It maintains the turn-based formula and SNES graphics, but streamlines all the boring parts (like healing outside of combat), makes combat more interesting and faster, gives each character an advancement choice at every level up, and most importantly, the game has a great sense of humor. This is very much a SNES jRPG, so those who hate the genre should stay away. But those who ever liked the genre should grab this, especially when it's on sale for a dollar along with Breath of Death. (BoD is not as good or as funny, so if you are going to play both, play BoD first.)

content:
y 16, 2014
												This game took everything great about Breath of Death and made it even better. Every mechanic and detail has been improved in this game. This is a must buy for fans of early JRPGs. Lots of jokes about other JRPGs, mainly from the NES and SNES eras. The battle system is fast paced and everytime you level up, you have a decision on what type of upgrade you want for each character. The game will last at least 7 hours without doing sidequests. If you do the optional stuff you can add another 3 hours. There are also other game modes to extend the playtime even further, including another storyline to play. The extra storyline is worth playing and can add another 5 hours to the game. Also, make sure you turn on the Developer Commentary option. It adds a ton of unque insights into every part of the game.

content:
r 3, 2015
Note: TL;DR at the end of the review.Story & GameplayThis game is amazing and the price tag is great! The story is hilarious with a great turn based fight mechanism, with a large variety of parthners with different weapons and specialisations this game is amazing! There isn't really much I can say about it but the story is innovative, funny dialouges and a large variety of attacks, weapons, unique effects for every level (unlike pokemon and a bunch of other 16-bit games which just up your stats).VisualsIt's a 16-bit game.OtherIt has controller support, and some gameplay mechanics that can really help in speeding up the game (a lot of 16-bit games are boring because of the slow walk speed or the slow turn based fighting as I've found) and as mentioned before every characters have new unique moves meant only for them after every level up. The algorithm automatically makes you fight more difficult enemies no matter the area so you don't have to waste your time grinding.You actually have to use your potions in this game, with challenging boss fights and a variety of abilities this games rating is:Rating85%TL;DRPros:+ Not monotonous like most turned based games+ Great story!+ Funny so it's basically made for casual gamers+ Hundreds of weapons, attacks and more+ Lengthy story+ Support for different controllersConsWhat?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
2, 2015
												Cthulhu Saves the World takes Zeboyd Games' previous title Breath of Death VII, an already charming and enjoyable old school RPG, as a template and improves every aspect. It's very much a loving tribute to both Lovecraft's fiction and the classic RPGs it follows so closely, and the game itself is really rather great. Combat is turn and menu-based and unlike some games in a similar vein once you get the hang of it the combat is capable of being very fast-paced, a big bonus given that no one wants to spend an entire game just being bogged down by unreasonable or agonizingly slow random encounters. This is furthered by the combo system in combat which makes for an interesting mechanic, and generally made more engaging due to the branching levelling system for Cthulhu and his party members with which the player can to some level customise the character's builds shaping their role in combat. Some of the dungeons can be a little confusing to navigate (the alien spaceship in particular is rather horrendous), but it is an RPG after all. Of course the main appeal of Cthulhu Saves the World over other RPGs is the story and the sense of humour, and pleasingly it's a riot. The sense of humour is very self-aware and totally unafraid to ridicule itself, the source material and the genre it lies in, with narrative quirks and violations of the fourth wall all over the place. This is also apparent in the developer's commentary which can be enabled, in which the devs are refreshingly frank, honest and frequently as funny as the story's  dialogue, making it well worth turning on. The Cthulhu's Angels bonus campaign meanwhile re-uses the vast majority of the main game elements essentially treading the same path, but the differing narrative and cast of characters remarkably manages to make it seem like a fresh experience all the same. Essentially this title is an engaging little classic-style RPG wrapped in an aesthetic and sense of humour that makes it all its own, and is more than worth the miniscule price tag for both this and Breath of Death VII in a double pack.

content:
30, 2015
 Cthulhu Saves the World Cthulhu Saves the World is JRPG, released in July 2011. Developed and published by Zeboyd Games.I bought this game in the double pack for very cheap like 0,50$ and honestly this game is absoluty worth that price. The game has a good art style and a lot of humor in it and references to other games.You play as Cthulhu who lost his powers and needs to be a hero to get them back. in your journey you will meet all new friends who will help you in your journey. Graphics wise the game looks good in a 8/16 bit style. The characters look good and the game has a nice art style. and it works really well with the 8/16 bit style. The gameplay is fairly standard JRPG. The combat is pretty basic but i does the job, the combat is pretty fast and there are no animations. You will get more players to put in your party up to 4 of them. On your journey you will get a enjoyable story and gameplay experience.I really enjoyed this game and i do recommend it. The gameplay is fun and the story is hilarious. The price for this game is cheap and I hope you pick this up, The double pack is worth it aswell.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, And checking out my Profile for more reviews.

content:
4, 2014
												I'll admit, this was an impulse buy when the combo pack dropped to $.99; however, I'm not disappointed at all. This is a fantastic game. The storyline is amusing, the dialogue is witty, the combat system is really good. I had a ton of fun playing through this. Though it only took me a few days to finish the initial playthrough, I skipped a few optional bosses (including the mega-boss in the Cave of Destiny), so a more adventurous player could find a few more hours of gameplay tucked away. Beating the game also unlocks Highlander and Cthulhu's Angels play modes; which allow you to play through the game with one character, or a team of Cthulhu's "groupies". All said, this is a fantastic game and I would not have been disappointed if I had picked it up at full price. Give it a go.

content:
17, 2014
												This game is a great twist on the Lovecraft Cthulhu lore. It's quite light-hearted and has some moments of being self aware also (Cthulhu talks trash to the narrator in the introduction and also comments on the fact that you can save anywhere- "What is this? A First Person Shooter?")It's a very simple and straightforward RPG in the style of retro and vintage 16 bit turn based JRPGs. There are tons of random encounters and there is a bunch of level grinding involved with multiple characters joining your party. The grinding could be a bit annoying at times but there is enough variety in enemies that it never gets too boring.All in all, if you like old games, funny games, simple games or RPGs, this is a game for you.

content:
9, 2015
												This is one of the few indie games I have played, And I think it is absolutely brilliant. The soundtrack - amazing, spot on OST for an RPG. The dialogue - funny, sweet and clever, I have wanted to read each bit of text in the game, the alternative developer commentary also gives some good insight as to how each dungeon was made, or the design of certain enemies and boss battles.The combat - Very good. Turn based. Any encounter can be your last. Save often, stock up on potions, choose upgrades wisely, and be ready to have some MP. Enemies can range from 2 at a time, to 6. Possibly more!Never have I played an indie game like Cthulhu Saves The World before. Seems to be overlooked in every perspective. I would have payed more for this had I known of it before. I picked it up with another game made by the same developer in a bundle for only £0.29. Massive, massive well done to the developer for the design of the game and composition of the amazing soundtrack. 10/10, don't miss out on this game!

content:
er 26, 2013
												Cthulhu Saves the World is a parody RPG where you get to play as Cthulhu and drive your enemies insane.If that and the cheap price tag weren't enough to convince you to buy and play this now, keep reading:The gameplay of Cthulhu Saves the World is based on classic JRPG mechanics such as random encounters and turn based battles. However this is mixed with more modern design elements to proved an improved, compact, experience. Battles can move very fast with minimal time wasted on attack animation and a very quick and responsive interface. There is also the combo system to add an extra layer of depth to your decisions in combat. Plus each area in the game limits the total number of random encounters, so you won't be stuck in an easy area forever if you have bad luck (There is also includes an option to force encounters in case you feel the need to grind past the limit).This parody RPG is filled with humor in its dialogue and enemy/monster description which will keep you entertained between battles. The game will only be around 5-7 hours for a normal play through, so if you want a classic JRPG type experience but don't have the 50-100+ hours to spend on a more traditional game, this is a great alternative. However, if you want to keep playing there are several alternate modes such as the score attack mode to test your skill, or the Highlander and Cthulhu's Angels modes to provide different experiences.If you liked Breath of Death VII you'll probably love this, and even if you didn't, you may still enjoy Cthulhu Saves the World due to its improvements in mechanics and visuals.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
er 29, 2015
												In the same vein as brother-in-arms Breath Of Death 7, CstW lampoons old 16-bit RPG tropes in a story that has you playing the bad guy. Cthulhu awakens to bring chaos and insanity but immediately has his powers removed by some goody-two-shoes jerk. So begins a quest to regain his powers and bring ruin to those who would oppose him.In terms of BoD7, CstW is everything that was but made bigger and better. The sensible additions BoD introduced such as limited encounters are still here, but the whole thing feels like a more complete package overall with sidequests and party construction. The humour remains consistently funny throughout and the joke never seems to wear thin, with enemy descriptions being a highlight of awful puns and one-liners that will make you smile and groan in equal measure.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
11, 2015
												Cthulhu Saves the World serves as a great tribute to classic JRPGs and the works of H.P. Lovecraft. It's funny. It's weird. It does what it sets out to do very well but it doesn't hold up quite as well when viewed simply as an RPG. Repetitive battles are to be expected but the combat does start to feel very sloppy as you progress through the game and realize that most of your moves will become obsolete. The story also does not do a lot to drive the player forward through the adventure. RPGs are time consuming... So in order to be worth your time investment, all the elements of an RPG (the combat, the characters, the story) need to work together to enrich the experience. Cthulhu Saves the World provides bits and pieces of fun but never really delivers a full and satisfying game. For a memorable retro RPG experience, it's best to look to classic titles such as Chrono Trigger and Super Mario RPG.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
2015
												This game offers very little besides the wacky title.What passes for a story is Cthulhu going around doing heroic things in his own way, which is sometimes something funny like saving innocent zombies from the thing controlling them but mostly things like returning a lost dog or healing an illness  by finding magic water. There is very little cast development, the characters stay mostly one dimensional and while the character concepts like a talking sword or an alien cat might seem interesting at first, very little is done with them.The music is nothing worth remembering, not even the final boss theme was that catchy.The dungeon design is bad, the only puzzles are barriers that can be opened with a button press and a falling/rising water level. The levels are designed to make the player get lost, probably to extend the short playtime, if you want to find the right way, take the path that looks the least like it will lead to progress.Of course, the graphics are also nothing noteworthy, they go for a "retro" pixel style, but this is just an excuse for being lazy with the graphics since they are nowhere near actually good looking detailed pixel art like: http://i.imgur.com/buH9JjF.gifThe gameplay is one good aspect, you are often in danger of dying and all of your HP get's refreshed after each fight, even if a party member dies, thus making even a victory with only one fighter left standing worth it. The only thing to look out for between fights is the MP count, since it isn't completely replenished. This game also makes buffs and debuffs useful, even in non boss fights. You still have a lot of skills you rarely or never use though. The danger of loosing is sadly undermined by being able to save anywhere, although this might not be the case on harder difficulties.Like any jrpg though, fighting get's tedious after some time and since there is little else worth looking at in this title, I suggest you avoid it.

content:
2014
												Ironicly, the title says all. The demon of insanity saves the world, with some friends! But not with yours.Cthulhu Saves the World is an old school based RPG with dynamic combats and a revisited gameplay.When you think you've seen everything in all RPGs, you're wrong. Cthulhu will show you some skills you've never seen before, and for a small, tiny, microscopic price.In this game you can create your own party of 4 characters, choosing between around 9 to 11 characters, each with different classes and abilities, you will have to try them all out to find their best skills to beat the bosses.In combat you can fusion with one of your party to create a unique powerful skill that can be as useful as useless, you will need to study every single detail to make the game easier.The story is counting many dungeons and villages which all have an event (zombie apocalypse, diseases, thieves), 2 sub dungeons to farm your experience if needed. Also, there's a limited number of random battles in a dungeon for you to fully  explore it after. But don't worry, in the menu you still can choose the "Fight" selection to battle and earn experience.The dialogues are funny and maybe for the first time in a RPG you're gonna read every single sentence.Finally, when you end the game, bonus modes and challenges can be unlocked to extend the gameplay.However, the "Cthulhu Angels" is the same story but with different characters (only girls.) and a different dialogue.Also, with the graphics, I was hoping for some chiptune music but the game has a quite disturbing music that comes over and over and sometimes in an inappropriate time.The game is a little too easy, especially on "Normal" which I did my 1st run today. The final battle wasn't so epic as in an old RPG game. I mean, a final battle should take around 10 to 30 minutes to make it. This one can be made in 3 minutes, even less. (In Normal Mode, I repeat.)Anyway, for this price you can't refuse to play this game, if you like RPGs or not, this one is made for everyone: for beginners as for harcore gamers. When the old RPG was too epic, Cthulhu gives some insanity to make it funny and it works.7.5/10 phrlyegxcr

content:
ber 3, 2011
												Cthulhu Saves the World plays much like the old-school NES and Super NES party-based RPGs, where you control the individual actions of a party of characters in battle.  However, unlike a lot of RPGs, it doesn't bog down in a ton of statistical details and lots of different kinds of armor and weapons.  Certainly, there are upgrades as you go along, but you don't have to buy a helmet, breastplate, greaves, shield, and boots to defend your character well; it's very much a pick-up-and-play type of RPG.  This isn't to say it isn't challenging, however; later battles may drive you nuts until you find just the right party and strategy to succeed.  The story is also engaging, and there is a lot of humor throughout.  Some conversations are downright funny, and even the narrator gets involved.  Character profiles are also winners.  One boss is literally a black hole; the profile says, "Now we're just getting silly."  Don't let the low price tag fool you; Cthulhu Saves the World is a great game.

content:
er 17, 2012
												Awesome little RPG that looks old-school but plays like an inspired, modern, and fun game designed with worthwhile mechanics. The music is quaint and reminds me of the "good old days" as do the sprites; however, the combat is thought-provoking and well done. It inspires you to win in as few turns as possible by increasing monster difficulty as time wears on and increasing rewards the faster you win. Dialogue is generally funny, cheeky, and satirical.Pros:Awesome mechanics like teleporting out of dungeons, tactical combat, and anytime fightsGreat dialogue and characters, found myself laughing regularlyGreat character progression by choosing how you level upComplex dungeonsOut-of-the-box Controller SupportCons:It's an oldschool RPG, so it takes a certain type of playerSprite graphicsRepetative (although good) musicFresh and fun oldschool RPG. Don't expect to take it seriously though. This comes in a dual-pack with Breath of Death VII. Although the games share similar mechanics and motifs, something about Breath of Death didn't give me the same charm that Cthulhu did. I'd recommend playing Cthulhu first and if you really liked it to then go through Breath of Death for more of the same; however, if you can only play one of the two, this is it. A

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 26, 2012
												Cthulhu Saves the World (CStW) is another tongue-in-cheek turn-based adventure role-playing game (RPG)--dear God--based on H.P. Lovecraft's short story, "The Call of Cthulhu." Similar to the Penny Arcade's third Rain-Slick of Precipice and Breath of Death, CStW utilizes the same Zeboyd's engine that continues to pay homage to old-school RPGs. If you enjoy good classic fun and love to sit back on the couch with a controller, CStW is a game for you. The story, humor and sense of adventure is a wonderful gift to casual gamers.

content:
r 6, 2014
												Thankfully this is a rather short RPG because I don't see how anyone could tolerate it much longer than that. Pretty much every dungeon is exactly the same, big sprawling maze with random encounters and the occasional chest. The hardest thing about the game is finding the next level of the dungeon, really. Mobs generally aren't too tough and it's easy to be overpowered in this game. The bosses are kind of a joke; even the final boss took practically no effort at all. The story kind of stops caring about a quarter of the way through the game and there's no sense of atmosphere at all. It's not even that f funny, either. There's some jokes but they're far too infrequent for it to really be a comedy game. The last dungeon has a big difficulty spike which is a bit unwarranted but even then, hopping into an optional dungeon and then back into the last dungeon basically destroyed all the challenge I was having. It's just... bland. I don't like RPGs in general and only got this in a bundle, and it was short enough for me to not get bored of it, at least. I wouldn't call it "bad" for what it is, but I certainly can't say it blew me away or anything.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 6
												Cthulhu Saves the World is a mediocre RPG as a whole- unfortunately, the the parts that shine are the quicker parts of the game.The humor is spot on, with a lot of amusing results for those players willing to search everywhere and interact with every object. Exploring a new town was the high point of the game for me. The music was pretty good too, though dungeon backgrounds resetting after every encounter was annoying... more on that later.The boss encounters are alright, there are some neat ideas but ultimately I hit on a no-healing strategy that crushed the back third of the game- difficulty was shallow and predominantly based around keeping the enemy strength from ramping up- all battles basically must end in 5-8 rounds at most, or enemies are too powerful to overcome as they gain 10% strength after each round. That's not too interesting, that just means go all out every fight!And that's what you have to do while exploring dungeons- go all out every fight and ignore healing. The only sustain you have is tied to your MP, and encounters are limited per area, so as long as the full party doesn't wipe, you're fine. Restoring to max HP just doesn't work.Dungeons also all feel exactly the same. Sprawling mazes that take way too long to navigate through, gold and XP feel worthless with the way they're curved, and equipment is scarce and usually obsoletes whatever you just bought. The menus are clunky, especially when it comes to equipping or checking character abilities.I will probably replay for the bonus mode with new dialogue and the like at some point in the future... after I'm no longer burnt out on labyrinthine hallways with a too-slow movement speed, even while running, filled with mindless encounters.

content:
er 2, 2015
												Cthulhu Saves the World is a game that plays and feels like Final Fantasy Mystical Quest. Well, except that it brings its own innovations to the table - the Unite attacks (which are awesome) and the round-based combat system (which pretty much limits the amount of turns you have to defeat your enemies). You'd expect a bland plot and forced humor; this is not the case. It's an amazing game with surprising depth in the gameplay; not just a tribute to the old JRPG games but a good game on its own - something the guys at Ubisoft should take note of when making something like Child of Light, a game that looked fantastic yet lacked in every other department.Limiting the amount of random encounters (after some fights they become optional) reduces the padding combat that plagued early Final Fantasy games.Another unexpected strong point is the soundtrack - a mix of JRPG-inspired 8-bit tunes with 80s heavy metal sounds just epic.I definitely recommend this game to every fan of the classic JRPG genre and Lovecraft mythos who also likes to have a good laugh. Well done, Zeboyd Games, well done indeed. Luckinly, I also have Breath of Death VII in my library to play after I finish this one. But I'll watch out for your other games and new releases too.

content:
ry 4, 2012
												I'm a big fan of JRPGS, however, since nowadays I'm a PC gamer, it's hard to find traditonal JRPGS. Cthulhu Saves the World is one of the few on Steam, and it's great. The price is stupidly low (it's like 3$ for two games), and you'll easily get 6 or more hours out of it. The game plays like an old Dragon Quest or Final Fantasy. You traverse an overworld, find towns, dungeons, etc, etc. The game itself is fairly linear, with a couple of side dungeons spread over the world. What makes the game unique in mind is the battle system. While it may look like nothing special, it's actually quite unique. Each turn that goes by the enemies all have their attack increased by 10%, what this means is that you'll quickly be overwhelmed. This means you have to stratgeize how to defeat the monsters in the quickest way possible. You won't be mashing 'attack' throughout the battles in this game. Dungeons can often be really maze like, which is a pain, but it's not a major problem.

content:
2, 2012
(This was written before the old recommendation system was updated into the review system we have today, so I was more limited with what I could write about this game and took on more of a tone where I was trying to "sell" this game to people. I plan to eventually write a proper, more long-form-ish review of this game whenever I can work up the drive to do so. So yeah, just take this "recommendation" as just that.)Okay, so we've got an RPG where you play as Cthulhu where you have to save the world in order to get your power back so you can destroy the world....Are you still here? Okay, fine. The game also has a pretty nice degree of customization that basically allows you to make each character fill whatever kind of role you like by choosing a skill to learn with each passing level....What, you want more? How about the incredible soundtrack you can download for free on the developer's website? What, am I the only person who cares about those things? Did I mention this game has a great sense of humor? Because it has a great sense of humor. Aside from the occasional references to games ranging from Final Fantasy to Bad Dudes, the game is filled to the brim with flavor text that always has something amusing to say about whatever it's describing. Need I say more? Yes? How about that there's another game just like this one packed in with it? And they're only $3 together? GO BUY THIS NOW OR CUTOFF FU

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
er 3, 2015
												So, in hypocritical style, after recommending Breath of Death as a fun, satirical take on classic RPGs, I am NOT recommending Cthulhu Saves the World. "Wouldn't a game whose premise involves the lord of annihilation and suffering plunged into the role of saving the world be worth a token recommendation because of its novel story line?" I can hear folks asking me. "Wouldn't a game by the same developers as Breath of Death be similar?"And the answer is a resounding 'YES' to both. Both games are nearly identical when it comes to level design, character progression, combat mechanics and funny/corny dialogue. I think the only difference is me - I'm clearly suffering from some sort of comedy RPG overload.This game has been sitting in my queue, unfinished, for at least a year now. And everytime I try to pick it up again, I am immediately turned off by the repetitive combat, grossly oversized dungeons and scarce loot. I am just not ready for more of the same. However, I still think the purchase of the bundle is COMPLETELY worth it. Maybe if you play Cthulhu Saves the World first, you'll have the experience I had playing Breath of Death (Read about it here: http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197989795433/recommended/107300/).

content:
, 2014
												Like Breath of Death, you can get this game for super, duper cheap and like Breath of Death, it's worth every penny.  This game has several play modes for crazy replayability, a polished combat system focusing on quick decisions, but also risk reward mechanics, such as making your enemies stronger but weakening their defense, and a story that is both humrous and endearing.  It's the Cthulhu mythos and all things lovecraftian made into a quirky Jrpg and the result is pretty amazing.  Also, this game has one of the best things in any Jrpg.  The ability to avoid random battles.  If you fight a certain number of battles in any dungeon, then you stop getting into random battles.  You can choose to grind and fight more, but this feature makes the game so much more enjoyable than your standard Jrpg.  Must play.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
5, 2015
												Nostalgic convenience.  Certainly brings back a lot of the fun of 16-bit RPGs, but includes a lot of nice additions that many of those older games did not such as being able to save anywhere at any time, conveniently placed restore points (especially before boss battles), ability to "one-up" if you die and want to try a battle again, free inns, able to warp to any town at pretty much anytime (even from dungeons), limited number of random encounters, and a run button.  I wish all those older games had these features as it pobably would have saved my parents from yelling at me to hurry up as I'm trying to fight my way back to an inn just to save my progress.  CSTW is really geared towards the fun aspect of these older RPGs.  Combat is overall simplistic and I found myself settling in on the same attacks over and over.  This may turn off some players but I didn't mind it too much.  There are some attacks and "team-up" attacks that I did not use at all or maybe once.  Some parts of the game aren't explained very well such as the "insanity" mode that some attacks will cause.  When I used it, the monsters caused more damage, but also took more damage from player attacks.  Apparently this mode can also unlock special attacks from certain monsters.  The monster's picture will also change slightly to show that it is "insane". There were a couple of nit-picky items that did not affect gameplay a whole lot but I thought were a little annoying.  First of all, the animations during the battles was very minimal.  The monsters did not move and only flashed when hit.  You can see your character's attacks in the form of a swipe or some kind of spell effect, but that was about it.  Also, some indicators on character status during fights would have been nice to show if they were poisoned, stunned, etc.  The game will tell you in the text box if a character's status is impacted, but its so easy to just click past these messages from habit that its easy to miss.  Overall this is a good game that took up about 20 hours of my time.  There were still some optional dungeons to complete and I may still do those.  If you like old-school RPGs or want to take a break with something more casual, then I would recommend this game to scratch that itch.  Plus you can get it on sale for less coin than what you probably have clinking around in your car's cup-holder.

content:

AUDIOStockVISUALRPG MakerDIFFICULTYToughVIBEcheesyCRAVINGcringeON SALEdon'tPROS: Writing an anti-hero is a bold choice. (Too bad it failed.) Battling itself is not that bad, takes an Earthboundish sort of approach. Overworld graphics are tolerable.CONS: I'm shocked to see how many people are praising it for its humor and story, and then I remember the current state of the film industry. I could not tolerate any text that popped up in Cthulhu Saves the World; It is the 9gag of video games. The dialogue is complete and utter trash. I've never been subjected to a more hideous form of unfunny. Every line of garbage uttered by the protagonist and the insufferable mary-sue anime girls following him made me writhe in discomfort.WORTH: please stopOVERALL: My health issues coincidentally took a turn for the worse around the time I bought this game. It would not surprise me at all if this game was so unfunny that it actually, literally gave me cancer. Direct exposure to it was like being viciously irradiated.SCORE: 2/10                                                                     Full Review Coming Soon

												With so many classic 16-bit RPGs on Steam trying to capture the nostalgia of the 90s, it becomes difficult to discern the fun ones from the awful ones. This is one of the latter.Gameplay is pretty self-explanatory for anyone who's played a turn-based RPG. The problem with this game is that it doesn't do anything particularly well to make it stand out from the crowd: generic monster types, humour that doesn't amuse, and a boring plot prevent this game from becoming what it could have been.

												This game is for all classic RPG lovers. This game is as simple as brilliant. You find yourself as the mighty Cthulhu, weakend by a strange magic, seeking for glory and honor to get your powers back. Can you rescue the land from the ultimate devil? All in all its fun to read the dialogues of the characters and to drive the story forward. The combat can be challenging if you are tired and just want to smash some random buttons, so be carefull. For the hardcore gamers there are some fine brutal modes which can make your playthrough to a pure mess. Good luck dealing with them! The playtime is around 10 hours depending on how much you explore.

content:
, 2014
												First of all, I have to admit this is my very first time playing something like this, and I found out it's not my cup of tea. So if you're into retro 2D RPG games, this review won't be to your liking either.Gameplay is pretty simple and the story does show a lot of fun. However, battles are overly simplistic and get rather repetitive pretty quickly. Story wise it's not very interesting. There is some funny interaction between the characters but I get the feeling it's merely the required minimum. The game is praised for it's humor. Let's get this straight: it's not hilarious. I didn't laugh, I didn't even snicker. It's just amusing. That's all. And not good enough to keep my attention/interest after the battles failed to do that as well. I guess it's similar to the situation when one types "LOL" constantly without really "Laughing Out Loud".Bottom line.If you're not into retro 2D RPGs you'll get bored. If you're into retro 2D RPGs maybe, just maybe and if you have pretty low expectations from a cheap game.

content:
ber 30, 2011
												Significantly better gameplay and humor compared to BoFVII. The game is longer than BoFVII but this also brings out some of the core problems with the gameplay. Bosses are true damage races because their damage increases in percentages per turn, leaving you to spam your most powerful skills until either you or it dies. The new "Insanity" ailment is supposed to add a layer of tactical depth to your skills but I ended up not even using them much since it has unpredictable (and often negative) results. Normal monsters are also frustrating since later in the game they get gobs of HP, often out damaging you while eating your attacks.If you have played a JRPG before you will find humor somewhere in this game for sure. Be prepared for some rage; all the difficulties are stronger than they admit, but nothing grinding can't fix.

y 28, 2015
												Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!This is a RPG game.Interface/Menu/SettingsYou can play on fullscreen.You can play on a big windowed mode.You can play on a Small windowed mode.You can play with the keyboard or controller.You can customize the controller.You can customize the keyboard.You can Choose between audio levels.You can choose betwen sound levels.There are 5 different save slots.There is a difficulty level.You are able to toggle commentary which is providing you backstory of the game.About the game.This is a rpg game like many others. You are wandering and playing as THE Cthulhu. Killing enemies, talking to other undead things, equipping your hero, going through towns and caves and many other things. The game combat is like a 2D text thing. You click on the target and attack and it is happening. Each time a turn has been passed for both sides. The Monster damage will be increasing. Slowly higher and higher. Death allies still get experience and they are able to level up. I do not think their experience get halved from others. But i can't confirm it. Attacking enemies on the same location will reduce enemy attacks.Enemies in battle gets stronger overtime.You are able to search for fights.Monsters that are insane will have a different sprite.The game has some funny moments. Including breaking The wall.The game has Great music.Story is decent.You can save manually.Once a fight is over, Everyone The HP and MP gets completely restored.You can equip your allies with weapons or armor.Other things.-------------------I Give this game a 8/10

content:
4, 2015
Time of completion:: 6 hours and 3 minutesDate of writing the review: 04.March.2015Difficulty I played at: EasyMy YouTube channel:  link  My rating: 5/10===========================I want to start off by saying that never before this game have I played any sort of top-down game, let alone a top-down (old-school) RPG like this one, so I hold no nostalgia factor for games like this one. This is from the perspective of a man who has been PC gaming since 2002 (was 10 y/o) and is just introduced to this type of RPGs.It's very difficult to give a good game a downvote, but even if everything else is done great, if your main mechanic (the combat) is done poorly, then the game loses all it's value and becomes bad and frustrating.Let's begin with the praises first:As I mentioned, most aspects of the game are done great, we will start off with the:VisualsThe art for the characters is great, when you see emotion, the picture changes according to the mood of the character. There is lots of variety between most of the monsters and you don't feel like fighting a different version of the same creature over and over again, even through some are just re-skinned and re-colored.SoundGreat ! Music is awesome and the sound effects while fighting vary from each-other.StoryAgain, great ! I love how you are a hero, but also not. You want to be evil, but you have to do good things in order to be able to do bad things. I know, right ? Mind=blown. The ending is very disappointing though, I really hoped that the opposite of what happened to happen.ControlsOh thank you, thank you, thank you for adding a sprint button, also thank you for making the "attack" command to be the default one. That helps with spamming ENTER in order to get out of the garbage fighting system as fast as possible....and now the bad...LengthI wish it wasn't this long honestly. Every dungeon frustrated me and I blitzed though it as fast as possible. I am so glad I chose the easy difficulty, otherwise I had to spend a lot more time planning my moves and forget where I was going by the time the fight is over.The other and most annoying thing is how the combat worksWhenever you are in a dungeon (or outside one, doesn't matter) you will constantly get interrupted by random encounters. For some it's possible to spam the ENTER key in order to pass them fastly, but for the later ones that option goes down the drain.Picture this: I am happily strolling down a dungeon, thinking of how to reach the end, I see the layout and think of the best path to take.... and all of a sudden.... BAM! A RANDOM ENCOUNTER. These things can take 5+ minutes. You have to concentrate, think of your best powers to use, look at your MP, HP and stats, look at the monsters' stats and so on. You get so involved it the fight that when you finish, you completely forgot where the hell you were going and forgot your plan completely.So you set off again, walk a bit, find the way and BAM! AGAIN A RANDOM ENCOUNTER. This repeats 30 times, making you walk the same path 30 times, seeing the same thing over and over and over(x27) again. This is not fun, it completely ruined the game for me. Exploration is out of the question in this game. I cannot enjoy the look of the dungeon even, if the gameplay constantly gets interrupted by random encounters.That is why I don't recommend the game and I am sorry I bought it (only for 31 cents, but even free I wouldn't have played it if I knew how bad it was). It's a shame really because the game does everything else fine.

content:
ber 20, 2011
												Cthulhu Saves the World is an interesting game.On the outside it looks like a simple turn-based rpg trying to copy classic rpgs like Dragon Quest, but with much more cheesier and non-proffesional graphics.But this game is a gem. On the inside it all comes together to make a very entertaining game.It has several innovations: Everytime your character levels you get to choose the improvement the character gets, you can only fight a certain amount of monsters in an area before you stop randomly encounter any more(with a option to keep fighting if you want), you get combo points for hitting enemies over time which you can then use on special moves to do large amounts of damage which when combined with the fact enemies get stronger every turn means each battle goes by pretty fast.Long story short, if you like old rpg games like Dragon Quest or Final Fantasy then this is a good buy, especially with the cheap price and being bundled with a similar game.

content:
er 4, 2014
												Both of these games uses the battle displays from ancient rpgs, think Earthbound, Shin Megami Tensei, or a numbered Phantasy Star (not online, the original games). Both of them rely on pretty decent jokes, although Cthulhu, being the second game they made, takes the ham way higher, and as a result is mostly funnier. Even though you never see your charathers in the battle, its still pretty involving, with stat buffs and debuffs as well as mana preservation, although it isn't quite as stressful as the games it's actually based on.The game helps you along with some major streamlining, especially in the inventory and telling you where to go next, although you can sequence break if you are willing to overlevel a bit.Although if this is the first time you've played one of these in a while, the game will probbably seem monstrously difficult, especially with its unique health refill feature giving them an excuse to use a set monster encounter rate.In all honesty, I think you should use PSN, GoG, wiiware, xbox arcade,  ceirtain indie releases, a compilation game (I can think of several sega genesis sets that include three phantasy star games, not to mention other awesome things in other genres) to experience this sub-genre in pure form.

												You get to play as Cthulhu.That's the only pro, and its just barely a pro, since that also means that you can be defeated, which...well...defeated Cthulhu's ideal purpose (which is to say, a mental assalant that cannot be killed and is barely seen. I'm very defensive over this as this game to me does Cthulhu wrong. Yes, there is a way to do him right and many games do it, but this one doesn't.)Behold: its an 8-bit game. More and more I'm starting to find this art style to be absolutely lazy. You got games like No Mans Sky that exists with its amazing colors but this one? This one settles for blocks.Right so its alot like Earthbound Zero.EBZ is very very hard, and is an RPG.CSTW is very very hard, and is an RPG. So whats the big deal? Well, at least in EBZ there's a clear "hey you're not ready for this area" line, in the form of the town Snowman, where you get terrifically powerful Wolves that you can't kill. Its its own area, right? But CSTW is like "hey look you were fighing level 2's in this cave system, so here's a level 8 enjoy"However, and this where the differences start: EBZ has a great story.This one does not.It came bundled with a second RPG in the same art style that I refuse to look at.Lovecraft fan or no, give this one a miss.4/10

												this is very similar to Breath of Death but with a few new features- you can fly and teleport around the world and swap around which characters are active per fight.  They've also improved the graphics a little, but the story and characters just aren't as good as Breath of Death's.  Wandering around a quirkily rebuilt post-apocalyptic world with a girl ghost hopelessly enamored with a mute depressive skeleton was more fun than this game's cascade of pop horror/cat owner references and boring protagonist.As with Breath of Death, there are a lottttt of pointless battles and exploring that are a pain to get through.  But my biggest gripe is that while Breath of Death's boss battles were fantastic and the one really enjoyable part of that game, Cthulhu's bosses are lame.  It's very easy to build one set of characters for disabling/aoes (for trash mobs) and another set for groups heals/combo builds (for bosses), which (at least on Medium) made every single fight in the game a breeze.

number of helpful: 6 of 23 people (26%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 14, 2014
												Nothing makes Lovecraft roll in his grave more than this game. I got it, expecting it to actually be clever, but soon found myself wallowing in misery and disappointment. It's supposed to be humorous, but the humor boils down to making silly faces and putting Cthulhu into only mildly ridiculous situations. There's a bit of fourth wall humor, but it's far from adroit. In addition, his out of character reactions only left me cringing. This is a god who makes people insane just by being seen, but here we have him idly chatting with mermaids. It's not funny, it's a failure to draw comedy from an emasculated creature of pure destruction. It's saddening that the only way they could conceive of a Lovecraftian comedy was to completely change the very fabric of what the elder gods are. The only relation this game actually has to Lovecraft's works is in name alone. You could name all of the characters and places differently, it would still be the same game.Gameply-wise, it's as bare bones as an RPG can get. There are no mechanics we haven't seen since the 80's. Every battle can be won by mashing the fight button, and there's a good chance you won't have to grind either. Some of the maps are too long, and the encounter rate will have you groaning over the tedium of having fought this same enemy fifty times in the past twenty minutes. I explored most (I say most because toward the end I just wanted to finish and be done with it) of this game's maps, and there are very few secrets to encounter. In fact, there's very little to the game besides the main quest. There's a few game modes to unlock, but I haven't bothered playing them because of how soul crushing the main game is.If you're an appreciator of Lovecraft's work, or if you think comedy should be witty, or if you like innovative RPG mechanics, this is not the game for you. You're better off spending your money on a hamburger, at least it won't leave you starving and depressed.

number of helpful: 4 of 19 people (21%) found this review helpful
content:
er 30, 2013
												Cthulhu Saves the World is an old-school JRPG, and by old school, I mean they ditch all modern innovations, ideas and sensibilities the have accumulated over the years. Which is the point, sure, but it just doesn't add up to much these days, unfortunately. The quirky humour occasionally hits its mark and the characters are, at first, a bit more interesting than the usual JRPG trope characters. However, there doesn't seem to be any more to them except the very superficial quirkiness.Gameplay is the usual old-school JRPG stuff. That is grind. Lots of monotonous grind. In the most baffling design decision I've encountered in a while, your party is completely healed after a won battle, but your mana is not restored. It might not sound so bad, until you realise that without Techs and Magics, your party is consistently and constantly getting beaten. So now you either: A) have to backtrack to a place where you can restore your mana orB) win fights without using mana. Which is not happening, not after the first area or so.Granted, the ability to save anywhere and start random fights almost anytime from the party meny are appreciated, but in the end you still feel like you are wasting your time. The jokes, characters and settings are interesting enough to hold your interest for an hour or two, but eventually the monotony of the gameplay and the frustration of the difficulty curve eat away at your enjoyment.

er 1, 2014
												This game was painfull to play. I sort of expected that from the price and screenshots but I thought I would give it a shot anyway and I was sourly disapointed. I got to level 20 by spamming the enter key during all fights, speaking of the fights they have tried to do the same thing as Pokemon (And I'm sure a lot of other RPGs) Where all you need to do is walk to find a fight. But who wants to spam the enter key 50 times, every 30 seconds of playing a game? At least in Pokemon you had to walk in long grass... All the dungeons look exactly the same and the whole layout of everything (Menus, battlescreen layout and anything that you need to interact with at all really), are a mix of pointlessness and confusion. I mean, why is "Chat" an option on the main menu? It would make sence if it was an online rpg, but all it triggers is the same conversation with an npc/party member, over and over again. Don't get me wrong I could never make a game at all and for that i respect the efforts that must of gone into this game, but it just wasn't fun to play. At all. I disliked the whole half an hour that i played this. I wanted to find quality in this game but when I couldn't I decided to look into other games of the same producer and I found that "Breath of Death" was almost exactly the same. The same layouts, the same everything with an exception to a few different enimes and npcs. I was pretty much playing the same game, so it gets a strong No from me. Do not recommend.

												Don't let the title or the picture fool you the very first time you gave this a glance. This game is AWESOME!It is very clear that the makers of this game have spent significant amount of effort into what this game is today. Not only is the playthrough well-thought out, several features such as the "No random battles" after you have done a stipulated number of them is a genius addition to the old-school RPG genre the likes of earlier FFs. Another feature here is the streamlined levelling system that allows player to easily understand and still make relevant choices in building their character. Along with that will be the reward/detriment effects that come into play should the battle be prolong. All of these, inter-alia, are solid design choices that separates this game apart from the rest.Coupled that with funny dialogues, characters and a multitude of monsters you come accross throughout your jouney is simply remarkable. With a small price tag that also gives a bonus RPG that is itself a stellar addition to any RPGer, this game has definitely exceeded my expectations.If you are not a fan of old-school RPGs, that leaves you 99% of the time looking at pixelated towns, characters, monsters however, do not expect this game to be otherwise. If you are one however, not having this is simply ftaghn! Get one right away !8.5/10

content:
ber 8, 2013
												CStW certainly gives a bang for your buck; at a mere $3 when not on sale, I can easily recommend it for it's humor (and if you so desire - challenge). You play as Cthulhu, stripped of his dark powers by a mysterious foe. The only way to regain them? Perform great heroic deeds. So begins the misadventures of Cthulhu and his colorful band of misfits you pick up (or groupies as I took to calling them). The game itself is not demanding on your hardware, as one might expect from a retro RPG. The combat is fluid, simple, and rewards your choices - on higher difficulties it can be utterly unforgiving, reminiscent of much older games. And as I’ve said, the game has a great sense of humor about itself. Personally, I found myself compelled to continue playing solely to see what the next joke may be. Grade: B. A solid game that will last you anywhere from 5 to 9 hours on the first campaign, with a few extras to boot. Humor and Combat are it's strong points; the plot is a parody more than anything.

content:
9, 2014
												Overall I felt that Cthulhu Saves the World is a weaker game than Breath of Death VII. Zeboyd's first game was more of a genre parody of JRPGs, while Cthulhu feels like a Lovecraft parody that happens to take the form of a JRPG - and not a very strong parody at that. It's silly Lovecraft, and not a clever overturning of Lovecraft's themes and conventions (like Breath of Death was for JRPGs). But that doesn't mean it's not funny and enjoyable. The fast levelling and combat did a good job of keeping me engaged, and the game is that kind that's short in a good way, so that it doesn't overstay its welcome. Full review here: http://postlaunch.blogspot.ca/2013/09/cthulhu-saves-world.html

content:
er 5, 2013
												Fantastic little RPG! It's packed full of fun characters and environments, with an enjoyable battle system and level-up system to boot! Its presentation is great too with appealing graphics and some great SNES-era style music. In addition to all this, the game has great replay value with various difficulty levels and game modes, and some other neat features such as character bromides, a bestiary and a full developer commentary. Finally, I'd be remiss if I didn't mention the exceptional writing in this game. Most RPGs fall flat on their face when attempting humour. Cthulu Saves the World is one of the only RPGs I've played that succeeds at being funny, even hilarious at times, with well-written dialogue and great comedic timing.For only £1.99 or less (I got it for 50p in a sale) there's really no reason not to own this game. I really can't recommend this one enough. Pick up Breath of Death while you're at it.

9, 2011
												Harking back to the yesteryear of the early 90's, Cthulhu Saves the World is a 2D RPG that comically parodies the age old genre while faithfully remaining true to its roots as well. An indepth leveling system combined with luscious 2D pixel art go well with the tongue in cheek styled humor of the antithetic Cthulhu who has been placed in the titular role as a "true hero" (against his will, of course). Along the way, he'll come across unlikely allies that will join him in his journey to save the world...only to destroy it with madness upon regaining his stolen power.I bought this in a bundle with Breath of Death VII for only $3. However, that deal may expire soon. Even still, this game is well worth the asking price of a measly 3 bucks and a true treat to any that yearn for a RPG that doesn't take itself too seriously or wishes to go back to the 90's, if only for just a little while.

												This and Breath of Death VII are two games that demonstrate an absolutely simple but at the same time revolutionary concept for JRPGs and gaming in general that I think more big time companies and other indie developers should take up on while still making games of the calibur they do now.In short, I speak of shortness, but not being cut off. A game that doesn't ramble, but tells its story and gives plenty of stuff to do along the way without feeling rushed. Cthulhu Saves the World does this within each of its campaigns but provides plenty of enjoyable replayability in its multiple game modes, unlockable content, simple on the surface but deep under the skin combat systems and absolutely -awesome- wit and charm. And to think, this is a game about an Old God trying to regain the ability to destroy the world and he's the protagonist! Maddness :O

content:
5, 2014
												This is a pretty bomb-♥♥♥ game.  At first glance it doesn't seem like much more than a mildly cute JRPG/Lovecraft parody, but once you get playing it reveals itself to have some pretty awesome mechanics that you don't see in your average RPG.The battle system is the main thing I want to talk about.  Functionally, it's a straightforward turn-based system a la Dragon Warrior, but some standout tweaks turn the battles from "standard grind" to "every battle is a fight to the death."  Enemies are generally capable of dealing out significant damage, and they grow stronger with every successive turn, pushing you to try and find the quickest way to dispatch them before your characters get wiped out.  The inevitably heavy damage would be almost unbearable in any other game, but CSTW balances it out by restoring your characters' HP to full at the end of every battle so you can get on to your next near-death experience.Character builds are somewhat unconventional, as well.  Rather than simply picking up stat gains with each new level, each character gains one or more new abilities that either grant them stat boosts or a power to use in battle.  Very often, the game lets you choose between two similar abilities, allowing you to customize the character's skillset toward your playing style while keeping true to their theme.  These aren't your old-school Dragon Quest spells, either - while some will feel familiar, I can't say that any other game has let me pelt my enemies with starfish or drive them insane with the caress of my noodly appendages.The Insanity mechanism is an interesting gimmick, as well.  At its core Insanity is just another status ailment, but where it differs from its predecessors is that the effects vary from monster to monster.  Some weaken under its influence, while others simply grow more vicious, and you won't know which enemy types have which response until you've already driven them insane.All in all, the graphics and jokes are a bit hokey, but the gameplay and general silliness make it well worth a playthrough.

er 27, 2011
												While the game itself may be considered short, or simplified by some, that is simply not the whole story. Cthulhu Saves the World is the quintessential RPG, in compressed format. While it may be shorter in terms of length (and due to the ability to run, and the fast scrolling text), it is indeed a complete RPG from start to finish. It is humorous, has a solid base of systems, and provides all of the satisfaction of a more drawn-out rpg, in less time. All in all, a fine investment of time and money.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
, 2014
												Very fun, albeit simple and very linear turn based RPG. There really aren't any special missions, mini-games, crafting, or other, later RPG game elements, but that doesn't mean this is bad. What this game does have over others is its uniqueness that I've yet to see, if not just heard about, in other games:When you arrive at a new area you have a number of potential random battles to be fought. Once you fight them all you don't have to worry about getting harassed any more! But, if you so choose, you can always instantly get into a fight with enemies, regardless of that "battles remaining" number. This is helpful if you needed to level grind a bit, for example.Winning a fight against your enemies instantly heals your full party to max health. That seems odd at first, but there are definitely a TON of very strong enemies that can kill you from full health very easily. You do NOT, however, restore your mana fully, but only to a very small extent. The mana is a much bigger deal because you primarily use "skills" and "magic" more than you would on basic attacks, which tends to be the common thing in older turn based RPGs.Branching level ups is a fun system that is somewhat in other RPGs, but more so seen as a type of "skill tree" that you see instead, and thus you can't remove and reallocate any point. It's interesting forcing your mage type characters into a fighter role sometimes, for example. The game definitely offers a variety of physical and magical attacks for each character, too, regardless of their normal intended archetype.That's really it, for the most part. There are secret dungeons, which is always a nice thing to have, and the other few unique game aspects, some of which I may have forgotten at the moment, but the game is hands down a great purchase, fully surpassing the "bang for your buck" considering the price tag of $3 which also gives you Breath of Death VII to go along with it.

												Plays like a early final fantasy RPG, I think. One might say that the characters are one dimensional and not illustrated well, that gameplay is grindy and that every area is a freaking maze. Or, one might enjoy the satirical humor of the different characters, take screenshots of the hilarious signs, gravestones, and drawers, or get a kick out of different ways to build the characters (there is a physical and magic split for almost every character, and the physical path for the ladies is OP.) er 21, 2015
												Madness and Glory to the great Cthulhu! Cthulhu Saves The World is an excellent, quiet well designed game that is a definite throwback to 'old-school' RPGs while being quite accessible to new players. I certainly enjoyed it, and if you can get in the double pack alongside Breath of Death VII it's a steal. Only problem I found was that the dungeons were far too long and confusing, and you might be put off in trying to complete some of them. Still, the particular mechanic of having a limited amount of mandatory dungeon battles is practically a(n old)godsend as it allows gamers of different types to approach dungeons how they wish, to a certain extent. If you can take your time with the game, it will reward you. The director's commentary is always a nice treat as well. Pros: Solid Humor, references to RPGs and Lovecraft aplenty, large world to explore, good variety of foesCons: Long, somewhat steep difficulty, dungeon design confusingly, MADDENINGLY tedious.Overall: 4/5

												Cthulhu is a parody that manages to succeed not only with its humor but also with its gameplay.  It manages to capture the essence of old school JRPGs while avoiding some of their pitfalls.  It's got the music, the graphics, and the interface that we all remember, but with the added bonus of capping random encounters in an area.  Leveling and encounters are fast, without fiddly little things that can bog a game down.  Besides that, you can't beat the price.  Hours of fun for less than a dollar - sign me up!

content:
6, 2014
												I personally do not know much about Lovcraftian lore, save what I have gleaned from an alll-night session of Arkham Horror with friends. Prior knowledge is not needed to enjoy this game though, important information (Cthuhlu is an elder god who cares little as to the fates of humans) is quickly explained and then pushed to the side as the jokes roll in. Four chapters in so far, and the laughter has not subsided. They come in the conversations between party members, the descriptions of the enemies, and in the insanity bestowed upon ones' enemies. The gameplay is a fairly simple turn-based RPG, with options chosen from a menu. The story is simple too: Cthuhlu is leading a bumbling (or maybe I'm the bumbler?) group of adventurers in order to become a hero so he may regain the power to destroy the earth. Currently it is less than a dollar due to the steam sale, but I believe it is worth the mere three-dollar full price. Zeboyd Games have created a delightful game that will keep a player entertained for as long as one is playing it.

9, 2014
												Overall I felt that Cthulhu Saves the World is a weaker game than Breath of Death VII. Zeboyd's first game was more of a genre parody of JRPGs, while Cthulhu feels like a Lovecraft parody that happens to take the form of a JRPG - and not a very strong parody at that. It's silly Lovecraft, and not a clever overturning of Lovecraft's themes and conventions (like Breath of Death was for JRPGs). But that doesn't mean it's not funny and enjoyable. The fast levelling and combat did a good job of keeping me engaged, and the game is that kind that's short in a good way, so that it doesn't overstay its welcome. Full review here: http://postlaunch.blogspot.ca/2013/09/cthulhu-saves-world.html

												To me this game was only playable on 'Easy' because it does not feel balanced at all on the other settings, and it plays like a rogue-like even though it is not actually marketed as one, and so if you want a new rogue-like game you should look into this. I like that you can play with a controller and that you can save at any point. The storyline was quite cool. I highly recommend having a pre-mission backup save reserved, with all your consumable items unused. There is virtually no loot in each level and therefore you won't find any additional healing items apart from what you are already carrying going into the level. One thing I really did not like about the game was that it occasionally sends these boss-type enemies at you, with huge amounts of health. Apart from that an 'OK' game, certainly worth the currently low price.Post-edit: oops, this was supposed to be a recommended game (with a caveat), thanks for commenting - it made me aware of it by looking at my review.

content:
1, 2013
												Extreme humor and no 4th wall to speak of, Cthulhu Saves The World, along with Breath Of Death VII, are some of the most FUN RPGs available on Steam right now. I mean it. Cthulhu, the embodiement of evil, rises from the sea after aeons of slumber to finally destroy the world... only to find out someone was already expecting him, and loses all of his mythical powers. He wants to destroy the world, but to do it, he must first recover his powers... by saving the world!Aesthetics of old, with a modern twist. Story is as great as it's absurd, it manages to improve on the classic gameplay. You'll really wish they had these simple - yet effective - features back then: they managed to COMPLEMENT the experience without disrupting it, not even a tiny bit. Oh, this also applies to Breath of Death VII.Comes with a bonus campaign (unlocked after you finish the normal game) with an entirely different take on the original story, "Cthulhu's Angels": what happens when the main character already knows the story (since you finished the game with him) and is just too lazy to go through it again? Everything derails into a fight for control over their own DESTINY.Definitely recommend. But play Breath Of Death VII first.

content:
er 26, 2013
												I didn't think Cthulu Saves the World would suck me in like it did.  The concept seemed a bit novel to me, an old school snes style rpg with Cthulu as the hero.  And the game was so cheap, I figured what the hell.  And I loved it.  From the very beginning the game pulled me in and I didn't want to stop playing.  It was funny, the characters were cool, I liked the overarcing plot, all the Lovecraft references, all the references to old school RPG's, the little facts about the enemies as you fight them, the ability to clear an area of enemies, the counter to let you know how many are left, the button that lets you just start a battle so you can easily level up your characters.  I loved this game from beginning to end.  There is no reason this shouldn't be in every steam owners collection.  Even if you think you won't like it give it a shot.  It's so cheap you're not really going to lose out on much if you don't like it.  Although I honestly wouldn't be able to understand why someone wouldn't love this game.

												Take on the role of a kinder and friendlier Cthulhu as he quests to regain his lost powers by becoming a hero to young and old in this throwback to early JRPG style games. content:
8, 2012
												The Good: Great use of the license, funny dialog, amazing music, varied graphics and environments, lots of attacks to learn and party members to findThe Bad: Graphics grate on your eyes after awhile, gets very hard, random battles bring the experience down a lot, doesn’t require much strategy to win battlesThe Cthulhu series from H.P. Lovecraft hasn’t seen much love in the form of games, but indie developers Zeboyd picked it up and turned it into a whimsical/parody 8 bit RPG and it’s done very well. You play as Cthulhu and pick up many party members along the way, but the whole point of the game is the great dungeon crawling that harkens back to the 80′s. You can attack like any RPG, but you have Tech attacks which are more powerful, magic, and then you can Unite with other members to combine devastating attacks. There are a ton of different attacks you learn when you level up, and you get a choice between two different things to level up with either stats or an attack, so by the end of the game each member has a huge arsenal to use.The game is very close to the mythology with bosses that are from the story, towns named after the exact towns from the stories, plus the art style matches. The music is amazing with sweeping orchestral scores (in 8-bit midi audio mind you) that really moves you and sounds great. The story is hilarious with Cthulhu trying to redeem himself and become a true hero to raise his city of R’lyeh, but his interaction with characters in the world is really funny. Of course the game wouldn’t be complete without a huge over map to explore that has some secret dungeons, plus the environments and dungeons vary with lots of loot and chests to find.However, the game’s biggest flaw is the extreme difficulty later on in the game, as well as the constant random battles which really drag the experience down. The devs tried toning this down by disabling random battles after you do 25 of them, but you will probably go through a dungeon before you hit that number. I also didn’t like how if you don’t level up high enough the end boss is impossible to beat, but each dungeon just really racks up the difficulty and requires you to grind a bit to get through the dungeon. I also didn’t like how you don’t really need a strategy to beat the enemies because you can just use the same one over and over through several dungeons. This causes the feeling of repetition to set in and makes you want the game just to end a little faster.While the visuals are nice and give you a feeling of nostalgia they don’t look good in HD and the lack of battle animations, and everything that goes along with 8-bit graphics grates on your eyes after awhile. However, the Cthulhu license is rarely explored so any game to do so is welcomed, but this game is probably for hardcore RPG fans.--Score: 8/10

												A delightful parody that pokes fun at RPGs and HP Lovecraft in general. If you like both, and can enjoy the mockery of it all, then pick up this game.However the game does have some faults.For one there's no explanation of the insanity mode when you fight someone.Also I don't remember seeing a map for the overworld, but then again older games didn't have such convience.Style-wise this goes for the 2D pixel art look like an old Final Fantasy.Characters have the ability to unify with certain others, allowing new moves.I picked this up on a sale, but if the game devs put this much heart into their next project I just might snag their stuff at full price.
